prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Pol supplement
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Molecular and molecular ion lines for obsering in N3 cloud

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The spectral resolution requested to cover the N2H+ transition of 1.57 km/s was chosen such that we can accuratly determine the velocity dispersion at individual lines of sight in the cloud. A high resolution of 1.53 km/s will also be utilized for the methanol transition as this is a known maser transition and is likely to have very narrow line widths.
All other observed trantions have been smoothed to a velocity of ~3km/s in order to approximatly match the resolution of the molecular lines we previously surveyed in this cloud using the VLA.

From previous measurements of the N3 molecular cloud, we know that the cloud size is ~21 arcseconds. An angular resolution of 3.6 arcseconds will match our observations of dust polarization and will be approximatly the resolution of our VLA observations.

Our sensitivity estimates are based off of previous observations of N2H+ in molecular clouds. Though this transition has not been observed along this line of sight previously, the requested observing time will be sufficient for an robust detection of the necessary line.
We have used a bandwidth of 1.57 km/s in our calculations so that we may make a detection without smoothing our data. Smoothing our data from this resolution would inhibit accurate dispersion measurements in the cloud needed to achieve the science goals.
We have chosen the default ALMA spectral resolution for continuum measurements.

From previous measurements of the N3 molecular cloud, we know that the cloud size is ~21 arcseconds. An angular resolution of 3.6 arcseconds will allow us to determine the magnetic field in the cloud without the much longer integration times requried for higher resolution observations.

Our estimate for RMS is taken from previous ALMA observations of dust in GC molecular clouds (Rathborne et al. 2015). The N3 cloud's dust continuum flux is not known, and we have decided to be conservative with our estimate in order to ensure a detection.
We have chosen the default ALMA spectral resolution for continuum measurements.

The nature of N3 is unknown, and the source remains unresolved in our highest resolution VLA data. In order to attempt to probe the source for structure, high resolution imaging is necessary. No structure has been seen in N3 at the ~300 mas scale, thus no emission on size scales larger than 300 mas is expected.

The flux density assumed for N3 is taken from extending self-absorbed synchrotron spectrum seen at lower frequencies and assuming that N3 will remain unresolved. While the requested time gives a high S/N, N3 may be resolved at the higher resolutions provided by ALMA, thus we request a high S/N in order to ensure that we will be sensitive to structure if N3 is resolved by ALMA.
We have chosen the default ALMA spectral resolution for continuum measurements.

The nature of N3 is unknown, and the source remains unresolved in our highest resolution VLA data. In order to attempt to probe the source for structure, high resolution imaging is necessary. No structure has been seen in N3 at the ~300 mas scale, thus no emission on size scales larger than 300 mas is expected.

The flux density assumed for N3 is taken from extending self-absorbed synchrotron spectrum seen at lower frequencies and assuming that N3 will remain unresolved. While the requested time gives a high S/N, N3 may be resolved at the higher resolutions provided by ALMA, thus we request a high S/N in order to ensure that we will be sensitive to structure if N3 is resolved by ALMA.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Located along the line of sight to the Galactic Center Radio Arc, the nature of the radio point source N3 remains a mystery after nearly 30 years after its discovery. Recent VLA observations have revealed a wealth of new information on this source, including a compact molecular cloud along the same line of sight. Observations suggest that N3 lies near the Galactic Center and may be interacting with the NTFs and the molecular cloud. However, despite our new insights, a physical counterpart for N3 still cannot be determined. We propose to observe N3 using ALMA in order to 1: determine if N3 represents a chance alignment of a background AGN, or a unique Galactic Center radio source, and 2: to examine the magnetic field of the N3 molecular cloud, and the magnetic field's relation to the field of the non-thermal filaments.
